Policymakers increasingly rely on computational models to predict the budgetary and broader economic impacts of current and proposed policies, especially those involving taxes and entitlements. Estimates from these models often determine a bill’s success or failure in the legislative process and public sphere.

The Open Source Policy Center's first focus is supporting community-driven projects that analyze the budgetary and broader economic impact of taxes. These models are completely transparent and freely available to researchers across the country. OSPC also provides an easy-to-use online interface that allows students, policymakers, journalists, and informed citizens to interact with the models and learn for themselves about the effects of policies.
The Open Source Policy Center is making policy analysis more transparent, trustworthy, and collaborative by supporting open-source projects that build cutting-edge economic models.
A LABORATORY FOR PREDICTING THE EFFECTS OF PUBLIC POLICY
Transparent
All of the projects we incubate are freely available and we encourage peer review.
Accessible
You can run the models yourself through our webapp interface or by downloading the code and using it with your own data.
Collaborative
We welcome anyone, whether you are a modeler, software developer, economist, or policy analyst, to help improve and expand the suite of models.

TaxBrain is an interface to Tax-Calculator, an open source economic microsimulation model available at www.github.com/open-source-economics/tax-calculator. The code for the TaxBrain webapp interface is itself open source and available at www.github.com/opensourcepolicycenter/webapp-public.

TaxBrain relies on a micro dataset that closely reproduces the multivariate distribution of income, deduction and credit items in 2009, extrapolated to 2015-2024 levels in accordance with CBO forecasts available in Spring 2015. It is intended to match similar but confidential data used by the Congressional Joint Committee on Taxation. Additional information on non-filers is taken from the March 2013 Current Population Survey. The open source code for this extrapolation is available at www.github.com/open-source-economics/taxdata, but the underlying dataset must be purchased from the Statistics of Income division of the Internal Revenue Service.

Proper use of this tool and a description of that use is your responsibility. That said, there is a community that is willing and eager to help you. If you have a question about how to use TaxBrain or interpret the results, a suggestion for making the interface or underlying models better, or knowledge of a bug, please send a message to our mailing list, which you can join at list.ospc.org/mailman/listinfo/users_list.ospc.org. You can also search through a list of bugs and upcoming enhancements by visiting the "issues" sections of the GitHub repositories. If you plan on publishing your results, it is highly recommended that you confirm with the community that you are using the tools properly and interpreting the results properly before you publish them. If you have a compelling reason not to leave a public note, email Matt Jensen at matt.jensen@aei.org.

Disclaimer

Results will change as the underlying models improve. A fundamental reason for adopting open source methods in this project is so that people from all backgrounds can contribute to the models that our society uses to assess economic policy; when community-contributed improvements are incorporated, the model will produce different results.

How to cite

These results were generated with version xx.xx.xx of the community developed and open source economic model, Tax-Calculator. Tax-Calculator was accessed via TaxBrain, an interface hosted by AEI's Open Source Policy Center. The exact simulation modeled here is available at www.ospc.org/taxbrain/NNNNNN

Neither the Open Source Policy Center nor the American Enterprise Institute maintain institutional positions, and the results from models accessible via the TaxBrain interface should not be attributed directly to OSPC or AEI.

Accuracy notes

The Python code that performs the tax calculations has been validated in a number of ways. First, Tax-Calculator results for a number of tax filing units have been compared to hand calculations performed using IRS tax forms. Second, Tax-Calculator results for a large sample of tax filing units have been compared to results for the same sample generated by a detailed SAS program developed by Dan Feenberg and Ina Shapiro of NBER. Third, a subset of input variables have been used to compare the results of Tax-Calculator to Internet TAXSIM as well as against the Policy Simulation Group's PENSIM tax module

Bugs aside, the results from Tax-Calculator might differ in comparison to those produced by Congress or the Administration for other reasons: modeling requires many assumptions, and neither Congress nor the executive branch publicize all of the assumptions they make. Examples of these include how income will be distributed among taxpayers in the future or how taxpayers will change their behavior in response to tax changes. A known difference, for instance, is that the distribution of wages in Tax-Calculator is assumed to stay the same in real terms for all years after the last year we have available data (2013). We know that Congress assumes this distribution changes over time, but they don't publish by how much. These assumptions are all flexible in Tax-Calculator, so please conduct sensitivity analyses. More assumptions can be made flexible in TaxBrain as well based on user requests.

User tips

Toggle the CPI control to indicate whether a parameter should be adjusted for inflation. NOTE: There is an existing bug with the CPI-inflation tags. Some parameters are being displayed as inflated even though they are not. This will be fixed by the week of October 25th, 2015.

Enter comma separated values into a field to indicate the multiple years of tax law. Similarly, do not use commas as thousands separators.

OG-USA is an open source economic dynamic general equilibrium model intended to evaluate U.S. tax policy. The model code and detailed documentation is available at www.github.com/open-source-economics/OG-USA. TaxBrain provides an interface through which a user can interact with and run this model. The code for the TaxBrain webapp interface is itself open source and available at www.github.com/opensourcepolicycenter/webapp-public.

OG-USA is an overlapping generations model. It is comprised of heterogeneous individuals, perfectly competitive firms, and a government with a balanced budget requirement. Firms make a static profit maximization decision in which they rent capital and hire labor to maximize profits given a Cobb-Douglas production function. The government levies taxes on individuals and makes lump sum transfers to individuals according to a balanced budget constraint. In its current form the model presents a relatively rich set of heterogeneous households, but less in the production sector and a simple government sector. Work in extending the model along these dimensions is ongoing. OG-USA interacts with Tax-Calculator, an open source economic microsimulation model available at www.github.com/open-source-economics/tax-calculator. It does so in the following way. The user will enter changes to the individual income tax code he wishes to evaluate via the TaxBrain interface. These tax policy parameters are then used to in the calculation of marginal and effective tax rates for individuals in the microdata underlying Tax-Calculator. These marginal and effective tax rates are then use to estimate marginal and effective tax rate functions that are used in OG-USA, determining how model households respond to changes in tax policy.

Proper use of this tool and a description of that use is your responsibility. That said, there is a community that is willing and eager to help you. You can also search through a list of bugs and upcoming enhancements by visiting the "issues" sections of the GitHub repositories. If you plan on publishing your results, it is highly recommended that you confirm with the community that you are using the tools properly and interpreting the results properly before you publish them.
